title: Three in one
text:
We have visited the garden centre several times, mainly for the plants which always look healthy and well cared for - I believe quite a proportion are grown on site. The bedding plants are particularly good and everything is reasonably priced. Limited hard goods are also on sale. Always tidy with good service. There is also a farm shop on site which sells super vegetables as well as other food such as bread, preserves, pickles etc with a separate butchery section. Also fresh flowers.
Situated between the garden centre and farm shop is a cafe with an entrance from each. Perhaps because of the position it looks a little dark and not very welcoming however there is plenty of seating with some comfortable sofas and chairs.Also a small covered outside area which looked scruffy. We just wanted a hot drink with a cake opting for toasted teacake ( large ) and fruit bread ( packed with fruit ) . Service was friendly and efficient. Had toddler with us who was catered for.

title: Breakfast
text: The pub has had a facelift since we had last visited ( moved out of the area ) and we were pleasantly surprised. Good carpark and exterior looks much more inviting. Inside cosy rooms with traditional look. We were there for a booked breakfast for our group . Warm welcome from the staff who were very helpful. The full English breakfast was excellent with the plate fully stacked with well cooked food , Served with tea and coffee, all for 10 pounds. Lovely views over the area with outside area

title: A little gem
text: We have been a few times to the Cock, off the beaten path but worth the effort. It is a comfy old fashioned slightly shabby pub with separate rooms and welcoming open fire in the bar - don't go if you like slick re furbished pubs. There is an attached cafe and shop which is open during the day. The menu is varied and there is always a good selection of 'specials '. All home cooked food so don't expect swift service. The pies are particularly good. Prices are very reasonable. We have also been for lunch, the ploughmans are huge. Real ales served. Service is good.

title: Party of 10
text: A country pub which has been re furbished in appropriate style with conservatory type extension. I remember it previous to this and find the improvements have been done sympathetically and retained the character of the pub.Attractive outdoor seating area for warmer weather.Booked a meal here for 10 including a baby some weeks before the event. Welcomed and seated straight away with baby chair supplied. The menu is well balanced with all the meats and fish represented , all with appropriate accompaniments. Price slightly above average but the food looks to be home cooked and prepared fresh. We had a cross section of dishes and all were enjoyed as full of flavor and hot.. Service by efficient and enthusiastic young people and atmosphere is good. We sat in the main part of the pub but have also sat in the extension which is equally comfortable and furnished in country style.

title: Country pub with rooms
text: A country pub which has been re furbished in appropriate style with conservatory type extension. I remember it previous to this and find the improvements have been done sympathetically and retained the character of the pub.Attractive outdoor seating area for warmer weather.Booked a meal here for 10 including a baby some weeks before the event. Welcomed and seated straight away with baby chair supplied. The menu is well balanced with all the meats and fish represented , all with appropriate accompaniments. Price slightly above average but the food looks to be home cooked and prepared fresh. We had a cross section of dishes and all were enjoyed as full of flavor and hot.. Service by efficient and enthusiastic young people.

title: Enjoyed the meal
text: Our first visit to the Haughmond as we live some distance away but will make the effort again. The restaurant was pleasantly decorated in country style, it seems there are one or two small rooms as well. Nice atmosphere as the place was full, mostly local repeating customers I should imagine. We had to wait a little while for the table, unfortunately not much room in which to wait and we felt in the way. The menu was imaginative and well thought out although we did have to clarify a few points before ordering as not always clear. Not a large selection but understand that the food is freshly prepared so difficult to have an expansive choice. Service was a little slow, again we are tolerant of this giving the nature of the establishment but we were decided chilly which is not really acceptable. We all enjoyed our meals, the main courses were a little on the small side so we also opted for desserts and cheese which we rarely do. Prices are good for the quality of the food. All in all an enjoyable evening.

title: Large pub
text: The pub has several rooms, all decorated in traditional style with plenty of wood in the old part. We were here in lovely weather so opted to sit out in the garden which has some interesting features and is very pleasant. Also children in the group. We ordered at the bar, not sure if this also applies for dinner but hopefully not ! We decided on some sharing dishes including a pizza as we only wanted light nibbles. It was a bit of a wait but the place was busy being good weather and a weekend. The dishes were interesting and tasty but on the small side for the price. The menu looked interesting and imaginative although the steaks were on the expensive side so can't drag my husband back to try the dinner menu. The children menu looked good .

title: Excellent nursery
text: Having recently moved to the area we have only just found Ashwood Nurseries although I am pretty sure I have seen them at gardening shows. Was impressed with the general layout and tidiness - no shrubs lay about diseased and lacking water here. Everything was labelled which is a feat in itself and displayed on immaculate outdoor beds and greenhouses. Reasonable range, prices are not the cheapest but sometimes it is better to get good stock than compromise. Also display garden which again was well looked after. Not the biggest selection of hard stock but adequate with a small gift shop. Restaurant very good with home cooked food. Looking forward to seeing John's garden which is open various times over the year.

title: Good home cooked food
text: The garden centre is well presented and kept immaculate. Mostly a plant nursery the plants are all in excellent health and well displayed in tidy beds and greenhouses. Hard stock is limited but sufficient. The cafe is normally busy when we go so entails a wait to choose food and pay. The food always looks very enticing which makes it difficult making a choice ! We normally go in the afternoon so have a cake and hot drink. Everything looks home cooked and the different flavored scones are particularly good. Prices are reasonable considering the quality of the food. The restaurant is a little dated but comfortable and overlooks the display gardens, there is also an outdoor seating area . If you are lucky you may get the tables around the open fire in the winter.

title: A must do
text: An exhilarating walk with a great view, the bridge is longer than you think. We walked from Manhattan and there is a fab view of the area on the journey back. Needs to be reasonable weather and not too windy . Great views of the river and there is the famous River Cafe at the base on the Brooklyn side. Read the plaques which give a brief history, evidently finished by the originators daughter in law after two tragedies in the family.

title: Iconic Skyline
text: One of the most iconic skylines in the world, especially with the new buildings on Grand Zero, although there are many worldwide jostling to overtake it. It can only be appreciated fully from the river so take the Staten Island ferry and stay on it for the return journey or you can travel over to New Jersey. We have taken the yacht trip up the Hudson and that is particularly good if you make the journey back in darkness. Ground Zero buildings can be viewed close up from the Plaza building

title: Great Foodie Experience
text: We always have a wander through the market when in New York, it is convenient for the High Line and the riverside attractions also. Some trendy shops selling interior decorations and clothing but the main attraction is the foodie shops and cafes. The specialist shops and bakeries sell best quality goods and are a delight to experience - particularly I like the fish hall. Also a fabulous shop selling all kinds of kitchenalia, a weakness of mine. Under cover so something to do if the weather is inclement.

title: Cosy old fashioned pub
text: Cosy pub made up of several small rooms with traditional decor. Large car park on the side with attractive small outside seating area, it is roadside but the traffic does not detract. After trying the food a couple of times we tend to stick to drinks and a packet of crisps. Real ale pub and I like the small bottles of Prosecco they serve. Service tends to be slow and not much customer appreciation is shown.

title: Great atmosphere
text: First visit for us, a party of 6 we all liked the feel and atmosphere of the pub and nice to have a friendly greeting. There seemed several small rooms decorated in country style - we all felt the lighting was a little too bright where we were sat. The service could not have been better or more efficient, friendly and caring without being obtrusive. Unfortunately for me the food just missed the mark. We had a sharing platter which was a little uninspiring although the home made pate was delicious. I had beef burger with stilton and mushroom, the burger was home made but very over cooked so a rather solid lump - I didn't think to ask if they cook them more rare which some places do. Also the cheese was soaked into the bread rather than dripping over the burger and I rarely eat the bread. Plenty of chips with chunky cabbage in mayonnaise . Others had steak and gammon , big platefuls and steaks were cooked correctly but pretty sure they were previously frozen. Shame nearly there with a little more thought. Prices were very good if the food was tip top

title: Great little place for drinks and eats
text: Hidden down a parade of shops this cafe is small and cosy although there is a handy conservatory across the way which is ideal for walkers and dogs. Always a friendly service and very helpful. Good selection of hot drinks and a super menu for casual eating at a good price. Recommended

title: First visit since takeover
text:
The centre was not stocked as well as previously but put this down to the new owners putting their own stamp on the place and getting rid of dead stock. Plants looked good and definitely cheaper than Wyevale. Good half price offers on garden pots. General stock quite low but renovations still going on in the main shopping area.
Had a snack in the cafe - scone and tea - which was fine. The menu looks much extended and prices seemed reasonable. The ladies do need to quicken up on the till as a large queue developed .We took our grandchildren to the soft play area which was very busy being half term. Good value if not so crowded but lots of children were too much for our 2 year old. Will pop in again to see how they progress.

title: Good old fashioned country pub
text: Nice to go to a pub which has not been stripped out and retains some old fashion charm. Good selection of straightforward food at good prices, ideal for a family meal out.

title: First time
text: Our friends have just moved to this area so we decided to give the Red Lion a try. First impressions are an attractive building which has been modernised. A winters evening it was warm and looked welcoming despite the opened out look and rather standardised seating.We passed on starters which looked quite interesting. Not sure why but found it hard to find something I fancied on the menu as did the other 7 who mostly ended up with steaks. I had the pork which was fine although on the cool side. The rump steaks were not too good and fillet did not have much flavor. Three had sweets and it worked out at 80 pound per couple with wine and drinks which I consider on the pricey side. Service was fine, friendly and efficient.

title: Interesting shopping area
text: Bustling area filled with locals and tourists. The centre square is a little scruffy and you probably need to keep a close eye on your wallet. The flea market entrance is off this square which is a busy area filled with shops selling all manner of items. Also close by are several Roman sites - Ancient Agora, Roman Agora, Hadrian's Library - connected by a row of busy restaurants running down the metro line. Bustling atmosphere with buskers. The far end of the market has an area of antique dealers selling all manner of items. Leads onto Psyrri area which again is an interesting place with plenty of eateries and specialist shops. Served by the Monastiraki metro

title: Great little place for drinks and eats
text:
Just opposite our hotel this small cafe / bar / bistro is also owned by the same family. It is open all day serving food throughout. Modern take on the interior with outside eating area. We stopped for an early evening drink and enjoyed the atmosphere and wine so called back for something to eat the following evening.
The menu is designed mostly for sharing in a tapas style so you can order two or three of the dishes. We tried the 'scallops' which we assumed were the shellfish but were actually little mounds with a sliver of scallop on top in a bright green sauce - not sure of the flavors but very delicious. The second dish were meatballs which again were very flavorsome in a tomato sauce topped with blue cheese. Third dish was salt fish and chips which were small piece of salt cod surrounded by strings of crispy potatoes, again absolutely smack on for flavor. Not sure why the servings are in 5's when it is a sharing dish. Very busy when we were there but service was quick, friendly and very professional. Good atmosphere with music in the background. Dishes are around 8 euros

title: Area between Acropolis and centre
text: Interesting and bustling area of narrow streets and small squares filled with touristy shops and restaurants.The shops do carry some better quality items but are aimed at tourists. Pleasant to stroll through and stop for a drink or a meal.

title: Can be seen from the boundary
text:
Excavated Roman site with Hadrians library at the far end, foundations and some standing columns. Interesting but not worth paying full price as you can see it all from the fence above the site. Signage a little better on this site than others but information could be found in a guide book.
We purchased 30 euro combined ticket which works out cheaper in summer but probably not so for winter as prices are reduced, also we found there is no need to actually go into this site and the Temple Of Zeus. Another thing to watch is that seniors have a cheaper entry fee.

title: Tower of the Winds
text:
Worth a visit with Athena's Gate and the Tower of the Winds being on the site. Foundations of shops and ancient pathways with some remaining columns. Signage is pretty sparse as with all Athens sights, giving architectural information but not a lot of history.
We purchased 30 euro combined ticket which works out cheaper in summer but probably not so for winter as prices are reduced, also we found there is no need to actually go into two of the sites. Another thing to watch is that seniors have a cheaper entry fee as well.

title: Largest Temple
text:
Remains of the largest Greek temple, would have been a spectacular sight when intact. Set in a scrubby field with only one information board next to Hadrians Arch. Worth seeing but no need to pay as it is clearly visible from the boundary and restoration work means it is fenced off.
We purchased 30 euro combined ticket which works out cheaper in summer but probably not so for winter as prices are reduced, also we found there is no need to actually go into this and the Roman Agora. Another thing to watch is that seniors have a cheaper entry fee as well.

title: Imposing gateway
text: Imposing gateway built by Hadrian to mark the boundary between his new Temple of Zeus and the old city. Standing by a busy road it is not very scenic around it but well worth a trip if going to Temple of Zeus or the National Gardens. Wander right up to it and no entrance fee.

title: Well worth a visit
text: This is a large planted area through which you can wander just a step away from the busy market square. We purchased 30 euro combined ticket which works out cheaper in summer but probably not so for winter as prices are reduced, also we found there is no need to actually go into two of the sites. Another thing to watch is that seniors have a cheaper entry fee as well. Steps up to the largest intact temple in Greece, which you cannot enter. Many statues and exhibits scattered around the garden with ancient pathways. Super view of the Pantheon on high. The small museum at one side is interesting, being filled with pottery and other finds. We would have paid to see this site.Take water if hot. Many restaurants run along the metro line so busy area with buskers etc.

title: Welcome green space
text: Large tropical type gardens with many walkways interspersed with statues and features. Large pool along with laburnum arch and gardens. Childrens playground down one end, avaries and animal enclosure at the other with a fish pool so there is something for the children. Nice to wander through after all the foot slogging and would think it is especially welcome in the summer. Unfortunately it is all a little neglected and needs some TLC but I am sure it is lovely in the spring when the arched walks flower. Also a lovely seating area covered with climbing plants - hopefully they will clean all the dead leaves once new season starts. No entry fee.

title: Easy system but usually crowded
text:
Did a bit of research before traveling and found you have to purchase a separate 10 euro ( one way ) ticket to travel from airport to city, also being over 65 we were half price so only paid 5 euros each. Terminal is on upper level of arrivals or you can get a lift outside the ground level exit doors. Booking office is very helpful and all speak excellent English - you need to go to the booking office . Easy to use with four main tracks. Journey is about 45 mins to city centre, we had just one change.The stations are very clean and airy and not too crowded unless a train has just arrived. Carriages are normally full. As with all underground we were warned by hotel to keep a close guard on wallets etc.
We also purchase the Ath.ena ticket which is 9 euros for 5 days and you can use it on underground, buses and trams so excellent value - no discount for pensioners. We used it mostly for short trips but you can also use it to go to the coast and get connecting trams which I understand take you down the coast, unfortunately we ran out of time to do this.

title: Off the beaten track
text: Called in for a quick drink on Saturday lunchtime. Cosy traditional pub in a picturesque quiet residential street, just off from busy Notting Hill station. Welcomed by the barman we sat in a comfy corner. The men said the beer was good and coffe was ok. Noticed they served cocktails and sharing charcuterie boards.

title: Plenty of steps
text: We walked from our hotel and climbed the flights of steps to the funicular. There we were approached by taxi drivers who said that they would take us to top fo 8 euros as the funicular would have been double that we took advantage. The drive took us around the other side of the hill and we were dropped at some steps which was quite a climb. On deciding to walk down we discovered we had hardly saved any walking distance by taking taxi so if you are relatively active it is quite easy to do complete climb - we are pensioners. Well worth the effort as the 360 degree panoramic view it incredible. Well designed cafe set into the top along with a small Orthodox Church. Of course we did it in February, the hot sun of summer may make it a difficult journey as there is no shade

title: Stunning
text: Our hotel was very handy for this visit so we just had an uphill stroll to the entrance. We purchased a combined ticket for 7 sites which cost 30 euros each - a great saving on summer prices but check if they are reduced for the winter season as a couple of the places do not need close inspection. We were approached by tour guide who wanted 100 euros for an hours talk a thought she did come down in price - feasible for a group but not just two of us. Wear non slip shoes and there are quite deep steps to the entrance although I think there is a lift. Stunning views and the Pantheon still gives a sense of awe. On reflection we wished we had visited the museum first as they show two interesting films which give background information. Information boards around the site and interesting to see the restoration. Luckily weather was perfect but imagine it is unbearably hot in summer.

title: Largest intact temple
text: Well worth a visit as the temple is very impressive although you can only walk around it. Set in large open gardens it is a peaceful place in which to wander. Also great views of the Parthenon and an interesting small museum full of pottery and other finds. In the flea market area which is a great place to wander with shops and antique dealers along with some great eating places a little further on rather than the busy restaurants which line the metro line . Paid for 30 Euro combined ticket which is not necessary in winter as admission prices are reduced but would certainly pay the entrance price for this

title: February visit
text: Good time of year to visit I can’t imagine what it is like in the heat of the summer. We bought a combined 30 Euro ticket which gives you entrance to other monuments , it would save a lot in the summer but prices are cheaper in the winter so I wouldn’t bother as some of the sites can be viewed from outside. Also prices are cheaper for concessions. Need non slippy shoes as it can be bare marble and rock. We were offered guided tour for 100 euros for an hour which was ridiculous for two of us, she did keep coming down but unless there are a few of you it is not worth it. Plenty of information boards and the view is terrific. On reflection we wished we had visited the museum first as there are two really good films shown which puts it more in perspective.It is impressive and interesting to see the restoration work. Also there is a viewing point in the gardens below which we missed.

title: Everything sweet
text: Small cafe with large selection of cakes and desserts. Attractive with outside seating area on a picturesque square. Traffic very close but not busy. Being February it was not too busy and we soon were served with glasses of water and a complimentary Turkish Delight. Big selection of cakes and desserts with optional ice cream for around 7 or 8 euros. I had the traditional filo pastry which was soaked in syrup and chocolate sauce whilst hubby had chocolate cake again drenched with chocolate sauce. The servings were immense and really sharing one between is the way to go as I could not eat half of mine. Not sure of the flavour of the ice cream which was not vanilla, perhaps something traditional. Well worth a stop if you have a sweet tooth. The surrounding area is full of eating places and picturesque shops.

title: Pleasant
text: We went for dinner as reviews were good and it was just around corner from our hotel. Generally we steer well clear of restaurants around tourist attractions but several had good reviews. Pleasant place to sit with outdoor heaters, looked clean. Service friendly and attentive and we were offered a free drink on choosing this restaurant. Had spinach pie and anchovies to start. The pie was very tasty but filo pastry was soft and not crispy. Anchovies were excellent served with some kind of breadcrumb. Main was prawns with tomato and cheese sauce on rice, absolutely loved the flavours and would recommend. Hubby had lamb which was very tender but lacking in flavour although it was served with thyme which helped. Shared walnut cake which was drenched in syrup and served wiyh ice cream. Bill was approx 70 euros with wine.

title: Well worth visiting
text: Attractive cafe restaurant in museum with outdoor area. We only needed a drink but had great service as if we were best customers. Sat outside in sun with a view over National Gardens. Coffee came with biscuits and beer came with tasty breadsticks with cheese dip. We were also refilled with water. All for under 8 euros. Lunches looked superb with local people lunching

title: A little gem
text: Nearly did not go but so glad we found time. A wonderful private collection beautifully displayed in the house of the collector. Set out chronologically and each room numbered so the route is clear. The early exhibits are of great quality and we were knocked out by the jewellery. Everything is immaculate and the house is pristine. Fantastic reconstruction of three rooms and lots of costumes. We were there 3 hours although you could spend more time if brain can take it. The restaurant is also well worth a visit.

title: Fabulous
text: The museum is absolutely stunning and exhibits are beautifully displayed. The museum is built to accommodate the footprint of the Pantheon so is large and airy. All exhibits were found on the Acropolis site or removed from the Pantheon for conservation. The top floor exhibit is particularly jaw dropping. Restaurant is good and not too pricey. Allow time to watch both films, one on conservation project and another on the history. Would recommend going here before visiting Pantheon as it puts it in perspective

title: Happy hour
text: Pulled in by happy hour prices of 1.70 for largish beer. Just had a wine anf beer and decided to order a dish of whitebait which were freshly cooked and delicious. Also ordered bread which brought the total to 15 euros so very reasonable. Can't comment on meals but food did look good. Typical touristy place with good service. Clean

title: Good start to journey
text: Arrived around 10am and breakfast items were on self service buffet. Bacon rolls, baked beans, omelette etc along with a good selection of fruits, cereals and juices. Too early for me to take advantage of alcohol. Self service hot drinks with biscuits also good. Busy but plenty of comfy seats and good facilities if you need to work. Seating has good view of runway at one end. Clean loos

title: New visitor
text:
Hadn't been here before and was surprised ny the size of the garden centre. In between seasons so empty spaces waiting for new stock. Not a huge plant area but plenty for all the family inside. The cafe was large and barn like but clean and tidy
with everything looking spick and span. Two sofa seating areas with magazi es which is a nice touch Had bacon sandwich with coffee for £6.20. Bread fresh although off a boring sliced loaf and bacon tasty. Cream available for coffee. Service by young people who were charming. Roast and dish of day served, also breakfast with sandwiches so menu is fairly restricted.

title: Rainy Monday
text: This cafe has been here for years so must be a testament to its popularity. Having moved from the area we have not been for some years but it still looks the same. We called in at lunchtime and were relieved to find it quiet as space is very limited. Rustic pine tables and benches with an upstairs seating area as well. Just wanted a drink and snack so choose a cheese scone and coffee, also shortbread and tea. A little confusing as to system of ordering and felt in the way as I was served because they were also bringing hot food from the kitchen - not sure how this works when they are busy. The scone was delicious and fresh, actually having a sharp taste of cheese which so many cannot achieve. Coffee OK and they had cream for serving. Tea good value as hubby got two cups from the teapot. Scone was very reasonable at 2 pounds but was confused to read that scone with butter and jam was 3 pound so not sure if I had paid extra for butter. Everything home made and the salads looked very tempting. Main dishes were 10 pounds with 2 salads, not sure how these went with the cooked food. Not the largest portions. Quirky loo which was clean.

title: Suitable for Quick Refreshment
text: Its Ok for a quick refreshment between shopping but personally would not waste money on most of the food available. It seems good value but the food quality and quantity are cheap. Sooner save my money for a decent meal elsewhere without queuing Restaurant is clean.

title: Large barn like cafe
text: Its Ok for quick refreshment between shops otherwise don't bother. Prices have gone up and don't represent value for money for the quality of the food. Large coffee although reasonable price is only cup size although you do get a pot of tea which is good value. Cakes are over priced for quality. Usually busy as they have a captive audience the area is pretty basic and uninspiring. Clean although I always think shiny pine tables are not the best as they get sticky. On another note we were disappointed with Boundary Mills which seems to have lost the quality shops and most garments looked as if they had been well looked through - although this may be because it is end of the sale season.
place: BB's Coffee Shop, Boundary Mill Walsall

title: Adjoined to the Antique Centre
text: Small cafe with an interesting menu that showed some imagination. Nicely presented and decorated. Had a cheese and onion toastie which was OK. Coffee was good. Had to wait quite a long time for food considering the cafe was quiet. Lovely to find an Antique Centre with a good selection of genuine antiques, plenty to browse around.

title: Quick pit stop
text: Broke our journey here for a quick refresher, remembering it from some years ago. Has massively expanded and glad to see the Antique Centre was still there. Quite confusing to navigate, didn't look around extensively due to shortage of time. Cafe looked as it it could do with a refurb, made for the soft sofas but they were absolutely filthy and I couldn't bring myself to sit there. Had a scone which was freshly baked and a sandwich which was OK. Lots of better places to stop really

title: Drink after a show
text: Dropped in the a late drink after a show. Very busy typical London pub with traditional decor which looked well cared for. Can't say anything about food as they had finished serving.

title: Quick drink
text: Typical busy London pub with great atmosphere. Just dropped in for a quick drink so cannot review food.

title: Superb breakfast
text: Atmospheric diner in American style with open kitchen. Very busy so we had to wait for a table, we were there for breakfast. Excellent selection on the menu and service was efficient and friendly. Six of us all enjoyed the food which was beautifully cooked and of good quality. Comfortable seating. Reasonable price for London and quality of the food

title: Small cafe in centre of village
text: Small cafe mostly catering for cooked food. We were after an afternoon cake so were disappointed by the choice but most people were enjoying light lunches. Coffee was fine and we were given a warm welcome.

title: Usual range of shops
text: Average shopping centre with usual range of shops including a large Asda under the same roof. Most of the chain shops are on the small side apart from the extensive new Next and Marks and Spencer. Primark has recently increased in size as well. Can be hard to park at weekends and there is not a good road system to the Centre so quite often queues of traffic.

title: Father Christmas Grotto
text: Took our granddaughter to see Father Christmas here, booked online to make sure of a place. The garden centre itself had a lovely display of Xmas decorations and lighting which we enjoyed browsing. The Santa experience was great, firstly met by Elves who guided us to mix reindeer food and paint a Xmas decoration. We then wandered through fabulous moving animal and snow scenes to meet Father Christmas. Afterwards she could choose a worthwhile gift from a great selection. Well worth the 10 pound charge ( plus 2.50 for accompanying adult ) , my granddaughter absolutely loved it.

title: Great finale
text: Small theatre which was full, very warm during the second half so go in layers. First half a little dull and probably this part of her life was a little prolonged. Great lead singer with Tina mannerisms . Show really did not warm up until the last 20 minutes when we got the full Tina Turner treatment. The girl playing a young Tina Turner stole the show.

title: Excellent value
text: Called in for quick snack and had the scone with jam and clotted cream with coffee. Also ordered toast and carton of custard for small grandson, all for under £7. Scone was homemade. Toast was thick granary with lots of butter. Breakfasts looked enormous and the sandwiches were chunky with lots of filling and side salad. Not for a special occasion but certainly worth a visit. Really helpful service

title: Must do restaurant
text: We have been many times over the years and watched it grow until it virtually occupies the street but quality not compromised. Always offered an amuse bouche and crisp own baked bread rolls. Food is always exceptional quality and plenty on the plate, quite often we share particularly the suckling pig and lamb which can be huge. Fish is of high quality. Normally sit outside unless chilly , the interior is cosy. Always a good atmosphere with excellent service. Wonderful restaurant.

title: Pleasant country pub
text: Cosy country pub in small village with busy bar full of locals. Dining area is separate with own small bar. Menu is reasonably varied with emphasis on steak which is well priced. Small problem with the menu as it is placed over other diners so quite embarrassing as it must spoil their meal if eating. Shared starters of olives, bread, whitebait and pate. Apparently the steaks were really good and cooked as ordered.he lamb shank was large and tasty. I had seabass which was on the small side but cooked correctly. One dessert was disappointing but overall everyone enjoyed the meal . With 2 bottles of wine and drinks it worked out at 40 pound per head. Service friendly.

title: Great Tapas
text: We always make our way to Chicos when in Benahavis either for pre dinner drinks or tapas. Very small bar with outdoor seating in a busy street, quite often have to wait for seats. Best and largest gin and tonic anywhere. The tapas are delicious with good selection, they are all cooked to order so may be a wait but well worth the effort. Very good prices.

title: Interesting menu
text: Lovely restaurant set in a small shopping complex on the coast. Comfy seating area for drinks looking out to the Med. Party of 10 and we all enjoyed our meals without complaint. Interesting menu with delicious fusion dishes well presented. Good service

title: Drinks
text: Just stopped in for lunch time drink, busy as was market day . Service was slow and we had to ask two separate waiters to get an order in. Live singer who was quite good but unfortunately we were sat by the speaker so was too loud for reasonable conversation.
